title: 111_hr5731
content: The "Veterans Mental Health Professionals Oversight Act of 2010" is the short title of this Act. It involves a review of mental health professionals within the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Veterans Mental Health Professionals Oversight Act of 2010" requires an annual review of mental health professionals employed by the Veterans Health Administration by the Inspector General of the Department of Veterans Affairs. A report on the review must be submitted to relevant committees within 90 days of completion. The report required by the "Veterans Mental Health Professionals Oversight Act of 2010" must include the number of full-time and part-time psychiatrists, psychologists, mental health nursing staff, certified social workers, other direct-care mental health staff, and administrative/support staff at each covered facility in the Veterans Health Administration's geographic service areas. The report must include the number of administrative and support staff assigned to mental health programs, full-time direct-care employees, unfilled vacancies for mental health positions, and the definition of a covered facility within the Veterans Health Administration. The Inspector General of the Department of Veterans Affairs is required to submit a report on mental health professionals to relevant committees and advisory groups for fiscal years 2004 through 2009. Additionally, an Advisory Committee on Veterans with Psychological and Mental Health Needs is established. The Secretary shall establish an Advisory Committee on Veterans with Psychological and Mental Health Needs, consisting of mental health practitioners, veterans, representatives from veteran service organizations, and other related organizations. The Committee will regularly advise the Secretary on mental health issues affecting veterans. The Advisory Committee on Veterans with Psychological and Mental Health Needs advises the Secretary on mental health care for veterans, analyzes data, collects information on mental health treatment, and submits annual reports on Department programs for veterans with psychological and mental health needs. The Advisory Committee on Veterans with Psychological and Mental Health Needs advises the Secretary on mental health care for veterans and submits annual reports on Department programs for veterans with mental health needs. SEC. 4. REPORT ON CHRONIC MENTAL HEALTH CONDITIONS. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a report on chronic mental health conditions to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs, including the number of veterans diagnosed, anticipated needs for treatment, and staffing and facility requirements for veterans of Operation Enduring Freedom and Operation Iraqi Freedom. The report must include the number of Veterans Health Administration facilities, equipment/resources used in treatment, funding required, and optimal panel size for mental health professionals treating veterans. SEC. 5. STUDY ON SUBSTANCE-USE DISORDERS AND REHABILITATION. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will conduct a study on substance-use disorders among veterans, focusing on barriers to treatment, the impact of early intervention services and counseling, and developing programs to combat stigmas. A report on the study must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs of the House of Representatives and the Senate within one year. The Comptroller General will report on mental health programs. The Comptroller General will assess the progress of the Secretary of Veterans Affairs in implementing the Mental Health Strategic Plan and the status of the Uniform Mental Health Services handbook of the Veterans Health Administration. A report will be issued within 30 days of completing the study. The Comptroller General will submit a report to the relevant committees and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs on the number of mental health professionals needed for the Mental Health Strategic Plan and the Uniform Mental Health Services handbook. Additionally, a report on any necessary modifications to the Veterans' Equitable Resource Allocation system will be submitted within one year of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General will submit a report on the mental health professionals needed for the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to meet veterans' mental health needs.
